review_title: The New Standard for Open World VR
one_reviews_text:
I should begin by saying I played this game on PC with the oculus link.
The creators of the game went to painstaking lengths to immerse the player through mechanics that no other game is doing, and not enough people are talking about. You can access your inventory, switch weapons, check your map, and quest info without having to pause or freeze the game. If you need something out of your backpack you grab your backpack, if you need to look at your journal you grab your journal. You have holsters all over your virtual body that work quite well after a little trial and error, and that is just the inventory mechanics.
the combat is exceptional. Rather than go through numerious examples I will share with you one experience that will give you a good idea. I approached a human enemy who was shooting at me. I had a hand gun, a machete, and a sword in my holsters. I pulled out my sword, chopped off their head, picked up the head and played with it like a dummy, stored the head in my backpack, took it back to the trailer base hub, and hanged the head on the wall as a trophy, where it still moves it's face everytime I pass it. Do I need to say more, buy this game!
And yet there is more. The crafting mechanic introduces an RPG element that creates a satisfying game loop. If you want stronger weapons and supplies, as well as a few skill perks, you need to collect junk you find out in the world. You store them in your backpack and when you get back to base there is a recycling bin you throw the junk into and automatically add it to the crafting station, which is very easy to use. 
It may not be as pretty as half-life Alyx, but in terms of mechanics it is far superior, and other game makers should be paying attention.

review_title: Hard to put into words how bad this is

Based on the title you can probably tell I didn't like this game. Every criticism I'm about to make obviously isn't going to be revelant to everyone: Most people love this game. But if the following sounds like it would annoy you, avoid this game like the plague:

- Stylized input latency to simulate the fact that your character is too weak to hold a handgun without it flopping around like a fish
- Never mind the above, the gun is going to disappear after a couple of shots anyway. Items have "durability" in this game. Which means you never *have* an item. Instead you have a weird ghostly shadow of an item, which will vanish into nothingness about 8 seconds after you pick up. (Things literally explode and evaporate in your hands - it's just a perfect own-goal as far as design choices go).
- You're starving... but don't think eating will help. Just as matter is immaterial in this game (see above), food is poison. 
- Two conflicting art styles. See that photorealistic wall? Pretty nice. Now look at that cell-shaded brick. And cartoon bricks in a realistic wall are just the start of it: how about impressively detailed, realistic gore on a bobblehead with a comic book face? The clash of styles makes for a game that's ugly when it really doesn't need to be.

Pros:

- VR controls move and feel super responsive. It can look a little funny when you turn a doorknob and your hand stretches like 10 feet for a split second though lol.
- Shooting guns and stabbing walkers/people feels extreamly good. The reloading is really realistic, which I like.
- I like the random encounters/speaking with NPCS. It feels really cool whenever an NPC asks "Hey, can you give me that letter?" And you physically rummage through your notes to hand the NPC the letter.
- Beating this game psychologically changed me in the sense that for some reason my sense of fear has been sort of...dulled? When I was walking outside IRL a cars tire blew up about 100 feet behind me, making a loud bang. I just sort of looked back and shrugged and kept walking. I dont mean for this to sound like some sort of edgelord comment, but im serious. This game did this to me lol. I used to be super jumpy at stuff like that but that feeling is sort of gone. Probably becuase I have been jumpscared 20 times by zombies breaking down doors, by the end I got used to it.

Cons:
- OK. This is one that I really hate. Why the does every living human enemy NPC have a gun? Were guns just being dispensed out of vending machines in the world? There are literally 0 enemy NPCs who have melee weapons. They. All. Have. Guns. 
- I dont like the fact that weapons cant be reapaired in this game. If your weapons durability is low, guess what, it will break soon and you will have to craft a new one.
- Whenever your weapon breaks, it makes a loud sound, brace yourself.

Whenever you enter a level, you can only stay in that level for a certain amount of time. Once time runs out (You can see the time tick down on the watch on your left hand), a massive amount of walkers swarm the map.

This game tugged at my thoughts for months as I saw people play it on release. I would constantly wish I had it. I got it a couple months after release, and Skydance really did a good job on fixing the elements their community complained about or suggested to add. The weight of weapons is beautiful and you always feel immersed in your VR enviroment especially with them listening to us and adding real-time crouching. You find the part you need and hear the bells toll. You know you're trapped big time. You pull out your knife and prepare to fight walkers. You kill one as you run out in the darkness of the early night. One down. You hear growls and realize you are surrounded. You struggle to pull the knife out of the walker's head, and it finally breaks free. Except that's the problem, it BREAKS. Now you're defenseless surrounded by walkers on all sides at nighttime. You run and run and are grabbed by a walker. You just barely grab a glass bottle and smash it on the walker's head. It stops, stunned, and you take that time to stab it with the bottle and run. You make it to your skiff and just barely make it out into the damp night back to your safehouse.

That is a real experience I've had. Get the game. Trust me.

review_title: This game feels like work. Not fun.
one_reviews_text:
I've tried the Quest and desktop versions, they're both fairly similar. 

My biggest problem with the game is how quickly weapons break and how many materials you need to actually upgrade anything. 

I'm a fan of zombie games generally speaking but this isn't comparible to Fallout/State of Decay or anything else you might want it to be comparible to in terms of what makes them fun. It is directly comparible in regards to things that frustrate. 

Weapon degredation can be a cool feature pushing you to gain more weapons/materials in order to progress, leading to loot feeling like a reward. Unfortunately the implementation here feels too severe, leading to looting feeling like busy work. Limited inventory space makes shuffling what you want/need feel like a chore. The cost of crafting supplies/weapons only adds to the problems with the previously mentioned issues, making the game feel more like a futile scrounge for materials than a game. 

The gunplay also feels lacking. I get that aiming shouldn't be simple but it seems like many shots carfully aimed just miss. 

The story is slow and feels pretty pointless as far as I've experienced.  

To add insult to injury I'm usually left feeling a little ill after playing for extended periods (I should note that even Skyrim with smooth movement doesn't leave me feeling as bad). 

I really can't understand why people find this so compelling in a world where games like Half Life Alyx and Zero Caliber exist. If it were my first VR experience I would probably have felt disappointed to say the least.

First off, this has nothing to do with the walking dead except there happens to be zombies and you can sort of smear guts on yourself. Otherwise, might as well have been called evil dead, 28 days later, or any other zombie game.

Don't ignore the warnings. The stamina system is a total joke. The melee system is a comical effort at best, but can occasionally work. It just doesn't work well most of the time. Gun mechanics are ridiculous. Weapon durability is just made up to try to add challenge to a bad design. Crafting is nonsense as well. Why would cooking gumbo somehow make your weapons break less easily? And how on earth do you craft a 45 ACP revolver out of thin air but your crafted blades look like someone just taped a bunch of junk together?

Suffice it to say the game suffers immensely by poor design and a lack of planning and coordination to make it fit the walking dead universe. It is frustratingly limited, and utterly inconsequential. You run around collecting trash. You craft other trash with it. You kind of follow a story if you can get things to work. But ultimately, there's no reason to care, but every reason to stay away.

This game is weak. Complete junk in a sea of VR options. I give it 2 stars because it can be occasionally amusing when things go your way. But mostly it's just a bunch of massive inconveniences and frustrations that don't seem to lead anywhere.

If you want a zombie game, get AZ Sunshine and leave this pile of feces where it belongs. In an un-flushed toilet bowl somewhere deep in the apocalypse.

As with almost any game it's incredibly difficult to get it right in every category especially in a genre like VR where it's still very new and unexplored. Saints and sinners get it right in the most important areas of combat, immersion and enjoyability.

Combat feels great and super 'realistic' for the walking dead universe. You start with small makeshift weapons and slowly work your way up to some bad*ss weaponry that makes you feel unstoppable and that is kind of where the game falls short. You spend most of the game working your way up to get the best gear and when you finally have it there is nothing to use it on.

The story is quite short sitting at an average of 18 hours but as of writing this I have 17 hours of playtime and completed about 4-5 hours of achievement hunting after completing the story so whether I'm fast or the estimate is off I do not know. Now there is nothing wrong with a short story but when the story mostly involves repetitive tasks such as fighting your way through a human safe house to collect intel or pump parts all the while looting the same types of items it can get a little tedious. The human AI does leave a bit to be desired as well because it's incredibly difficult to be killed by them and even if you kill one of their friends in the next room with a loud gun shot you can still sneak up on them.

Despite this I found the game immensely fun and thoroughly enjoyed the game. It's clear that the main reason for the shortcomings I've mentioned so far is that they've had to invent the basics because it's in VR which is why I have no problem with them and look forward to a potential sequel which will allow them to spend more time developing other areas now that they have the basics.

I know The Walking Dead: Onslaught is made by a different studio but I have no doubt they will have learnt a lot from S&S and If Skydance choose to make a sequel they'll be able to do the same to Onslaught.

I did part of the game before using a trainer, since it's only singleplayer and there's absolutely nothing wrong with using a trainer in singleplayer. Meleeing was a stamina hog. So when there's a group and you don't have your gun or it broke (all weapons break after not much use), to kill a walker with melee, you pretty much need a blade of some sort, then (if it has the proper stats) you can decapitate it, otherwise you have to stab its head, push the blade to the brain, then rip it out. When you run out of stamina, you can't pierce the brain.

There is weighted melee, so swinging fast makes the game have to catch up. When you go to stab a head, you might not have enough momentum and it'll miss or clip through the head. Then sliding the blade in is awkward after it took so much momentum.

Once I progressed and got a Katana, it was awesome. Every time I grabbed it, it made a *shink!* sound and decapitations were a breeze, even one handed. I used it more than I used any gun.

Once I beat the game, I could go back and kill walkers, but there's little to do outside of that. Multiplayer would've been nice, though Onslaught looks like it has that covered, and will have actual characters, and some weapons that aren't in this.

*one glaring issue I had, and I only noticed this after having used a trainer, was unlimited spawns. To leave your safe area, you approach a small rowboat with a map on it, then you pick an area and it loads. You have a watch on your hand with a circle and a small highlighted part at the top. When the bar reaches that point, the church bells ring and it attracts walkers. Sometimes I would overstay my welcome (I guess) and the bells would ring. The map would not let me leave and walkers would never quit spawning. I had to kill myself and respawn to fix the issue. It wasn't because of the trainer, it's just how the game works.

review_title: One of the best purchases to date!
one_reviews_text:
My family gave me an Oculus for Christmas last year. I've dabbled here and there with a variety of VR games. Few really good and most fair to partly cloudy.  As such, I was admitted a little hesitant to invest in this game.

  Since my wife and I are hunkered down as a result of Covid-19 harbor in place mandate we took the chance...  Well I'm here to tell you "money well spent".

  My wife is not as big a geek as I am and to be fair, she gets a little irritated when the controls are not intuitive and if they are not flexible and forgiving for not being "exact".  She picked up the fundamentals of the game no problem and in short order she was playing quite intuitively.

   We thoroughly enjoy the resource hunting/management, RPG and survivalist aspect of the play mechanics.  Being older (In our 50s) we appreciate the cerebral aspects of the game as much as the zombie bashing.

  Graphics are not ultra realistic but more stylistic which IMHO is a smart move as too many games try too hard to look pretty but fall flat on actual game-play...  That's not to say the art is poor in any way but quite the contrary.  The artists did an excellent job of putting details in the right place to maximize the ambiance and to suck you into the world...  Same with the sound. The rag-doll physics of the zombies and NPCs are well done as are the physical way objects can be used as tools and weapons.

End of the day, all I can say is I cannot recommend this game enough. Hope folks find this review helpful!

review_title: A Great Game If You Like Rubbery Arms
one_reviews_text:
The good:
They did a great job with immersion, more than any other game or experience that I've seen in VR, I really feel like I am walking around in New Orleanes.  The details are excellent.  The rush you get the first time you stab a walker is awesome.  
It took me a while to understand the goal in the game, comparing and collecting inventory items to upgrade the workbenches.  At first I was put off by the inventory system, I can fit 27 computer keyboards in the same space that gets filled up with 27 little boxes of matches... because each item is really just its scrap resources.  Balance.
The immersion I mentoined before is over the top, walking through the streats, sneaking around in buildings, the use of the flashlight.  All perfectly executed. Even the music, this is one of the few games I turn the music down but not all the way off. 
The depth here is also impressive, progressively building your resources, how you handle the missions, how you treat people when you encounter them. This game is a cut above the rest when it comes to handling 'menus' so that you don't feel like you are playing a video game.
The bad:
So why only three stars?  The entire reson this game goes from 5 stars down to 3 is holstering and rubbery arms.  Yes, this feature is so immersion break, and game breaking that it makes the whole experience comical.  The weight of a single pillow, or even a full pack of cigarettes sends your whole wrist in to a rubbery twist, like gumby.  
Your 'game hand' not being where your physical hand is can be quite disruptive when you thought you put your weapon away, but dropped it on the ground somewhere instead.
In real life even a 10 year old can pick up a baseball bat without their arm going limp out of control. I've never seen anyone looking visibly encumbered by a full pack of cigarettes.
In short, this game has a lot of ground breaking features, the mechanics, the mapping, building up your home base... and almost entirely ruined by a silly feature.

review_title: Finally, a good, story driven game.
one_reviews_text:
TL;DR Finally a great, polished action packed game with a story, but not without its flaws. The price point is very appropriate. 
[UPDATE] 2 Days after Launch, Devs patched the worst of the bugs and oversights, such as the gun weapon angles which have been completely fixed. Simply great work by these devs. Truly. 

Refreshingly, this game manages to do something that VR has weirdly struggled to achieve, and gives us an engaging story, with plot, and objectives, and crafting, and decision based outcomes, AND action, and combat, with physics that I'd say fall a notch or two short of Boneworks and B&S, AND beautiful, unique and polished graphics. I've heard the spacial audio is pretty cool, however, Oculus seems to just not care that the Quest microphone drivers don't work, so I couldn't tell you personally.

That said, don't expect anything much more groundbreaking than that. The game isn't 6DOF, which means, no croutching, bending over to pick things up, or real life verticle movement. In 2020, that's a pretty big draw back. The stamina and health system seems way too punishing, as does the time sensative nature of the storyline. (or rather, time simply moves way too quickly.). Each area is big enough and dressed up enough to give you the slightest illusion of open world, but are still very much not. Interactivity is minimal. Basically, if its not a door, weapon, or usable item, you can't interact with it at all. As of the new patch, I haven't encountered any bugs.

I've been playing this using the alpha 'hunch' option, that I'm glad was patched in so soon after launch. Crouching with a button was lame, and while the alpha fix has  minor issues, they pale in comparison to not being able to crouch.

What can I say about this game? It's fast become my favorite VR game to date. Boneworks is interesting, and shows what VR can be, but it falls on its face every five seconds. This? This is the stuff. It doesn't feel like a proof of concept. It feels like a smart evolution.

To nitpick, survivor AI is pretty dumb, in ways that break immersion at times (running through their own barb wire traps cause they heard something?), but that's about all I have for complaints.

The gunplay and melee weapon interactions are best in class, with loads of clever touches. Want to empty the bullets out of a revolver you've found that's about to break? Simply open up the cylinder and point the barrel to the sky. Want to break through wooden boards? Either lever them off with a crowbar, and smash through them with an axe. It all makes sense.

The balance of resources and enemies seems almost perfect. I love the gameplay loop of running against the clock when out in the city, and then having all the time to complete tasks near the bus. I love how the enemy density shifts around from day to day. I love hunting for supplies.

review_title: Well done. Please add the option to save
one_reviews_text:
Before buying the game I have read many reviews on the Oculus Store. Most of the comments are positive. Among the defects, however, often are mentioned: the slowness of our character; the problem of crouching; the low intelligence of the NPCs and the little depth and "explorability" of the levels. My personal opinion is that the speed of our character is almost never annoying or frustrating. It only becomes tedious when we need to travel through parts of a level that have already been explored and we want to avoid wasting time seeing again the same areas. Crouching has perhaps been improved since I purchased the game, because isn't a problem at all. Like in other games, we will use the crouch button to walk in stealth mode. All the movements and interactions seems natural. A little exception for the hands that stays opened and rigid when in the natural position. NPCs are divided between Zombies, which don't necessarily have to be brilliant, and other characters. Indeed it happens that the latter recite a too repetitive script and that they “losing their memory”. But I think this depends on the fact that many NPCs are strongly characterized, they have their own story to tell. They do it every time we interact with them, but at least the dialogues are credible, well-acted, interesting. In short, NPCs have personalities, and this is more important to me than their tendency to be repetitive.

 The levels are well studied. Here, however, we should not get confused. The Walking Dead Saints & Sinners is not an open game, like Fallout or Skyrim, where, for example, we can enter in almost every home and get lost in a world designed to credibly simulate the depth of reality. I don't think this goal was even part of the developers' aims. In TWDS&S the levels are designed to tell a certain story, or to deepen it always by following precise narrative lines. Not all software houses have tens of millions of dollars to create credible and complex worlds. This title seems pleasant, engaging, well structured, very well made and credible. It is a pearl, even counting that the levels are a bit "rigid".
The only problem is the save system: it is too rigid and we will repeat the same actions more and more to go ahead in the story. And this is a little frustrating and boring.
For the rest: I really like both the graphics and the stages, full of atmosphere. Our character is well animated. Physics has been compared to that of Boneworks. It is actually a much better compromise. Unlike Boneworks in TWDS&S there is a feeling that everything has its own weight and inertia without however excessive and unpleasant effects that makes the gaming experience frustrating, nauseating or cumbersome, as sometimes I happened to notice with Boneworks. The sound is fantastic. The radio in the bus (our base) broadcasts music that I would like to have as a playlist. Sound effects have something familiar (sometime reminds me to BioShock, I don't know why) and pleasant. 

The story is well articulated, convincing and engaging, also thanks to the strong characterization of the NPCs we interact with. Managing resources is pleasant, because our backpack is not the usual Mary Poppins bag, bottomless, but can only contain a certain number of objects. Slowly VR is collecting a number of titles capable of holding the comparison with the best AAA non-VR games. And i’m happy and grateful.

review_title: Fun at first, but lacks replay value
one_reviews_text:
As a huge fan of the Walking Dead series, both the show and the TellTale Games, I was hyped for the release of a Walking Dead title coming to VR and bought it day one.  While the experience was fun in the moment, the game slowly became more tedious as I progressed.  This game shines quite heavily on its outstanding approach to melee weaponry, and differs from other games with similar mechanics.  When I pull a shiv out of a zombie's head, I'm not just going through the motions, I need to apply extra effort to get my weapon back.  The voice acting in this game was also phenominal, the voice actors really brought the characters to life!

Now, onto why I'm rating this game 3 stars, and it really pains me to do this but I was left rather unsattisfied in the end.  First and foremost is the scrapping mechanic.  If you want to level up your abilities, you need to be constantly looting around for junk scattered around the world, which is exactly what you would be expecting in this sort of game.  The problem I have with how this was done is that loot respawns everytime you revisit the same area.  Sure, loot starts to dwindle as days pass, but if I can loot the same house day after day, it's left me wondering why there are still any supplies in there at all if I've looted it the night before.  My progress on the world doesn't leave an imprint of what I've done, and I start losing a connection with the world I'm in.  This is especially true with how frequent zombies respawn.  Killing zombies does not feel rewarding, and I found myself just running through the levels towards late game.  

The flashlight on the chest needs a better angle, because I'm constantly having to hold it manually to see things right in front of me.  The story itself was short, and the ending feels unrewarding if you go the good guy route.  I would've liked to see more companionship afterwards instead of a "kay bye!"  It makes the entire adventure seem pointless otherwise...

People are all hyped but wait a week for reviews to start dropping on this game. When you really get into it, the game design is very flawed. The combat is fun and, short of some games like boneworks, hellsplit, and blade and sorcery, it has some of the best melee combat I've seen.

Where it fails is literally everywhere else. The level design is boring and dull. Too much grey darkness to hide the cartoony graphics and too little interaction with the world. Yay, I can pick up the pre-gened bottle off the ground and break it and stab a couple (literally two) zombies with it before it breaks. That's nice. But those things don't respawn and you'll find yourself running back through empty streets with terribly respawning zombies. For instance, I turned around and broke LOS with a wide-open area 20 feet away from me, turned around 1/2 a second later, and there was just a zombie standing right in the open where he clearly just popped into existance as soon as I turned my head. The model of the zombie I just killed was laying on the ground in the exact same spot. My thought wasn't "cool, more fun combat" or "haha funny respawn mechanic" it was "oh, great, another durability knock to my one and only shiv that I have left in a way to artificially create difficulty".

And I'm not bad with resource management and I don't get hit much, but the 2nd level of the game forces you to fight a seemingly endless stream of gun-toting humans while you still have very little and just really took your first bite of the game. The pacing, mechanics, and resource management kill and fun I was having crawling through decrepit houses and stabbing zombies in the face.

For the life of me, I don't even know if I'll be able to bring myself to finish this game. I'll try, but it seems more trouble than it's worth at this point. Lots of reaching over the left shoulder for inventory management and scrambling around for wine bottles that don't respawn. The game actually punishes you for playing it.

3) The diary is ace, and I love the tabs. But why do I have to both touch them with my finger, and at the same time press a button? Just let me touch it with my finger. The story:  As you'd expect of a big name like The Walking Dead, there is an immersive story you can really sink yourself into.  You feel like you are in the boots of this character in the true Walking Dead comic universe. If you love the dark horror, post-apocalyptic world of the Walking Dead, this is a must have.

But it doesn't end there.

The physics:  Friction on textures, weight, collisions etc. are simulated with realism.  You can practically feel these objects, in a manner I've only seen done in Boneworks and Blade and Sorcery before.  In my opinion, this Walking Dead game feels even better than both of those games, in terms of these special physics. And despite all this, the performance and graphics can run incredibly well. I have not felt any stuttering or experienced any strange physics events that break immersion, such as in Boneworks where your hands can get stuck behind solid objects, twitching entities etc.

And another thing to top it off is that the developers listen to the community.  When this game is released there were things people were not happy with, features such as physical crouch were missing.  Upon seeing these reviews of the game, the devs patched in a physical crouching function within a few days!  Incredible.

review_title: Absolutely brilliant, just not for me
one_reviews_text:
This is a weird review to write, because it’s both a 5* and a 3* review at the same time. Hear me out...

This game is technically amazing. The graphics, audio, physics, immersion and story are all thoughtfully crafted and expertly delivered. My first hour in this game I was just blown away by how well the devs had done delivering something so truly remarkable. 

The gameplay is designed to keep you always on edge and makes sure that each decision you make is thought through. The stakes at every turn are high and the fear and anxiety this creates adds a layer to the immersion that I’ve not seen before. If you’re a fan of the survival horror genre, you’re going to love this. But...

I’m not personally a fan of the slow grind style of games and that’s where my trouble started. After the initial WOW wore off, I started to get bored very quickly. 

The concept of a stamina system is brilliant but the implementation here left me walking at a snails pace, tracking back and forward from points on the map unable to run lest my max stamina be reduced and I use precious resources to replenish. The starting stamina for your character is so ridiculously low that after taking 3 poorly judged swings at a zombie I was “too tired” to hold it, or to run, so basically just got munched.

Similarly the durability element of the weapons is another great concept, but for me just became frustrating. They just seemed too weak. Constantly diverting resources to have basic weapons got tiresome for me very quickly. 

Like with the point about stamina, it just took the fun out of playing the game being sooooooo completely underpowered from the beginning. Essentially you start the game as a geriatric with a lung condition who is armed with weapons made of Lego.

For me it felt as if the difficulty bar was set just a little too high. You can upgrade so many things to improve your character, but between the incredibly slow walk speed and limited back pack slots, everything just feels like it takes so long to do that. 

If there was a difficulty setting in this that started you with a bigger backpack, bigger stamina and more durable weapons from the offset I would probably enjoy this game much more.

TLDR: 5* for the game itself, 3* for how much I personally enjoyed it. But you should definitely give it a try, it’s phenomenally well done. Just know that if you want a bit more of an action game you may want to wait for TWD: Onslaught

TLDR: Almost perfect, but not without a flaw. Thumbs up!

This game is genuinely scary (despite the stylised character graphics) but amazing fun to explore! Gore is high. 

It involves crafting and resource management; building tools and creating supplies to keep your arsenal stocked and food in the cupboards. 

Combat is very violent with accurate physics, requiring you to push that little bit harder to stab a screwdriver through a walker's skull. 
Missions are played in a day - a timer on your watch tells you when night will fall and zombies will start to horde on you. Your stamina and health are reliant on food, medicine and rest. It can be brutal though, as running and swinging weapons drains stamina quickly... and then you die.

This would be a perfect VR game - and probably my favourite game - if your position was no so locked in place. Some interactions require a button click, whereas others are physical actions. You cannot physically crouch and have it simulated, you have to toggle a button to crouch in game... 
This sorely needs to be changed by the developers. 
Having very recently played Boneworks and had so much (perhaps too much) physic[s]al movement, this feels disorienting and strange.  Wilson's Heart is similarly restricted, but it makes more sense in the narrative nature of that experience. When playing Skyrim VR, I enjoy leaving a dungeon and lying down on a grassy mountain... 
The opening cut scene has you stood on a row boat floating through New Orleans witnessing the apocalypse - but I couldn't sit down in the boat (as you would IRL) without pressing a button and then sitting down! 
I do wonder if these are deliberate choices on the part of the developers to make an excruciatingly violent and frightening experience feel more like a video game(?) Hopefully a patch in the near future - please?!

All in all, a very good game. Going back now to play some more!

EDIT: 28/01/20 Just tried the update/workaround to allow crouching in game. It's sooo much better (although not without some glitches)! Hopefully this will be fully implemented soon - maybe it was an outstanding item on the to-do list at launch?

review_title: Totally lives up to the hype! GOTY imo!

You can't take too long either since the bell will start to ring after while and hordes of zombies will arrive. Love this game! review_title: Great fun but there are a few problems
one_reviews_text:
First off the game looks awsome and is really fun to play, but there are a few problems to the game in its current state.
 
You can't crouch in real life but have to press a button. Now it's not a problem gameplay wise but it can be a let down with impression.

Walkers can spawn just about anywhere you are not looking. I have had some walkers spawn behind me when I was in the streets right when I turn my head around. While this is not a huge problem but it can wear down weapons rather quickly, which can be a problem if you come across a large number of walkers and you just ran out of durability on all of your weapons.

Now I don't know if this is just happening to me or if it is a bug but I can't seem to advance to day 4. Whenever I try to drink from the flask to go to the next day, I am met with the consumption bar just not filling up. I thought it might just be for the flash but I tried it on soda but I was met with the same result. I tried restart the day and even when to a different area but I still could not advance to day 4.

Can't be played well if you are left handed. You have to aim and move with the same hand which can be a bit of a pain when using a gun. So if you play this left handed you might have to stay still to use weapons unless you can somehow manage that.

This has to the one of the best games ive played in vr so far. It has everything lots of games lack like good physics, interactive gunplay, and nice atmosphere. 

There are a few things i wish they could add and a few ideas id like to see. One of which is the flashlight. (The school level terrifies me) i wish there were two levels of light and depending on what one you use the slower/quicker your light runs out. Maybe have a brighter mode and a bit bigger of an angle for the light (having to hold the journal slightly left in dark areas is weird). Co-op and pvp obviously would be amazing in this game. Id also like some on the go crafting. Maybe if you have two items you hold them together to make something. Another thing that gets annoying is the slow walking. I wish the walk speed was slightly faster but i can see where it plays in for zombies catching you if youre low on stamina. Another thing is melee pve, id love to have a fight against people with axes and bats with deflecting attacks and swinging at openings. One last thing is i wish there were more side quests. The main story is amazing but after i beat the game i wished there was more to do with people other than being mugged.

Out of minor nitpicking i think this is a step in the right direction for the future of vr. I really enjoy this game and i think the devs did a nice job bringing us into the world of the walking dead. I look forward to future updates and i will be constantly replaying this game. Amazing job team! Keep it up!

review_title: The best VR Zombie game hands down!
one_reviews_text:
Edit after recent update!

This game has everything you'd want from a Walking dead themed survival horror game. You have to scavenge for food and rescources to survive requiring you to venture out into the world. There are 3 different crafting trees that use a large variety of rescources, combined with a reasonable but limited bag space you will need to prioritze what to scavenge everytime you are exploring.  You also have a stamina/hunger system, which depletes quickly from swinging weapons, sprinting, and vaulting/climbing objects. Not being careful with your stamina while fighting and avoiding the undead will lead to a quick death as you will be unable to fight them off or get away if you tire out. Your max satmina also decreases untill you are able to find food and replenish it.

    There are many more great things I could say about this game, especially regarding the spot on physics, but honestly I recommend just purchasing this game and seeing for yourself. This is the new Gold Standard for a true AAA survival horror experience and for VR in general. This game is worth every penny.

Edited portion: Devs are very responsive to feedback and fixed the previous issues I was encountering. I have also progressed farther into the game and would like to add the difficulty ramps up with each day you survive. You really get the feel that you are scraping by to survive and its great!

   
Overall I'd personaly rate this game a 10/10 and would recommend this to anyone with a VR headset!

The  melee mechanics are a breath of fresh air, arguably the thing that sets this game apart. With that however, the gun mechanics seem like an after thought, aiming is janky, and the weight mechanics of the shotgun actually made it droop off its axis to the point where during a hoard encounter, i couldnt grab it with my other hand since the barrel drifted way out of reach from where i was pointing.
There is an unnecessary lack of durability in the weapons, guns can barely survive a firefight which yes it may make planning more critical but ultimately it just makes me unable to combat the AI that has unlimited ammo and gun durability and removes the option to be aggressive. It would be nice to get a repair option, I hate scrapping guns because i cant build them up or maintain/ mod them. Fixing durability, fixing the stamina issue, adding more honest gun implementation and perhaps a 2 person multiplayer option would really solidify this game as one of the best on vr atm.

Great game guys! Few small things, when disabling walk direction of HMD / Freelook, please fix so you move direction / orientation of controller. That's the only miss bothering me. And snap turn, please let us pick the angle amount the turn is, I would love to have it like 15-20% more each turn. These 2 are pretty big useability issues that were somehow missed in this great game !!!

Wow!!! What an awesome game!! Immediately sucks you into the action. Extremely immersive experience with a very detailed and realized world. review_title: Alpha patch within the first three days
one_reviews_text:
A game-changer. This feels like an actual AAA survival game compared to the other zombie shooters on the market. The game can actually make you completely forget about reality and scare the doughnuts* out of you, making you question if you have the courage to continue playing through the next level.

They have addressed several concerns (including the physical crouching issue) after not even a week since release. (look at the updates section and follow their instructions on how to enable physical crouching -in alpha at the time of writing-)

10/10

I'm about 2 hours in and so far I'd say this is the best VR game I've played. The graphics are VERY good and run smoothly on my 2070 Super rig at Ultra 150% Pixel Density on the CV1. 

Overall, the combat is enjoyable, it has some cool features, maybe nothing revoluationary, but really really solid. The crafting is also awesome. 

Another reviewer complained about the stamina system. I have to disagree, I think it's awesome. It makes you think, you always need food and bandages and you need to be smart, it's a survival game after all. 

That being said, the same reviewer mentioned that touch controls could be utilized better and I agree. I think there are some places where button presses would not normally be necessary, but it isn't that hard to get used to. I.e. there is a built in crouch in game. This game doesn't make you bend over constatly, because you would be doing it ALOT. 

If you want a story driven, very polished, VR game set in TWD universe then this is the game to go with. Just seing NOLA built out is so awesome.

Original: Purchased but not available for download.

Update: Item became available to download after an hour or so.

Very impressed so far. Very high quality environment and animations for a VR game. It reminds me of the quality of an Oculus Studios title. Definitely the next big premium VR title.

Stamina feature is a bit annoying  since it seems to be more important than health. You use it to run, attack, and survive getting grabbed by walkers. Regaining the stamina is a be tricking since you have to get your bag out. You get to go to one location each day to gather supplies and complete mission objectives. Each day there are more walkers and fewer resources. Crafting seems interesting enough with three categoes and many tiers of unlocks.

Finished the game, update 2: Overall I find two areas lacking. First is the disregard for the precise one to one tracking offered while playing in VR. The stamina system hurts this feeling with your in game representation being suggish and imprecise when low on stamina. Early on this happens a lot and gave a mixed first impression but if you dont stay out until the horde then this shouldnt be a problem. Second, there isnt enough interaction with other survivors and factions. There are two NPCs who give you missions and two factions. You cannot join the factions. There is no alignment. It felt like this game was marketed toward you being able to choose sides and help alot of survivors and do side missions. You make a handful of choices but mostly just fetch, and the fetching makes you violate faction safe houses even if you would have wanted to align with that faction. I finished the game around day 24 and at that point I had been done with all three tech trees for about ten days. It seems as though you will not even get all of the crafting recipies if you make certain decisions so beware. The overall art and game design shine though the annoyances with the stamina system and lack of content outside of roughly 8-10 missions.

This game is a great VR experience, it really does set the bar higher for VR games.   Everything in the game feels solid, from the environments to the objects you can pick up and interact with to the zombies themselves. The combat feels just right, especially the melee - you really have to shove that shiv hard into the skull to kill zombies, and then you really have to pull it out again.

The environments are detailed and well presented, with loads of objects to pick up and use. One of my favourite moments so far was being chased around a room by a zombie, grabbing a bottle, smashing it against a wall then using to kill the zombie. 

I could go on with the positives, but there are so many I'll just repeat what I said above - it sets a new standard for VR games.

It's not without it's flaws though, and I hope the devs fix them (they seem very responsive so far, so maybe we'll be lucky!).

There's no physical crouch, instead there's a button for it. I understand there's a work-in-progress version of physical crouching in the latest update, but it really needs to be in the game proper. I don't actually mind the button crouch, but it would be good to have both options.

The stamina system is a bit over the top. You can't run for very long and getting into a fight with two or more zombies, even with single-handed weapons, is going to tire you out pretty much to death. I really hope this is tweaked upwards - it breaks you out of the experience a bit when your character gets tired quicker than you do.

Zombies seem to respawn. I don't mind this happening between days, but when you've killed a zombie in a yard, it shouldn't be back after you've just been going through your inventory. If you've cleared a room or a house or a yard, you should be safe there. It's just part of the zombie survival thing.

Even with these flaws the game is great. It would be an easy 5 stars without them though.

My very first impression of this game..it's so SLOW!  My god, I actually stopped and took a break washing dishes out of sheer boredom within my first hour.  That has never happened to me in a VR game before.  I could understand when you're sneaking, but even your default walk speed is just......so....slow.  And sure, can sprint, but it tanks your stamina insanely fast.  I'm honestly not sure if I have the patience to slog through this, and I'm on the fence about whether or not to just get a refund before I hit the point of no return on hours played.
The crafting system is interesting, your holsters and inventory are easy to use and intuitive, but the problem is when you're trying to grab items off the ground, half the time you inadvertently draw your weapon out of your holster instead.  I've lost a couple perfectly good knives that way somewhere along the line.
Weapons handle realistically.  No waggle-fighting here, you have to grip that axe with both hands and your strike had better be on point.  That was very well done, as is the gunplay.  (Which, given the oversaturation of shooters and arena fighters that have set standards of both great and terrible combat, shoddy weapon handling would just be unforgivable at this point.)
So yeah.  It's got potential, but that walk speed...UGH I can't stand it.  If you've ever played Skyrim or Fallout, you know how when you're overburdened you walk at that agonizingly slow pace?  Imagine that...but that's your default.  That's your normal speed, all the time.  That really needs to be amped up by at LEAST twice.  Even if they increase the zombie speed to match, that's fine, just turn this into something other than an overencumbered "you can't fast travel while enemies are close" simulator.

review_title: The VR Zombie game we've always wanted

Day 20...Available supplies have dwindled. The Dead have grown in number!
Having put some time into the game and unlocked some nice toys to tinker with, I felt I was ready to leave some feedback...

Really enjoying the WD:S&S experience. A nice range of weapons to use, with firearms having different reload mechanics. Weapons and items have "virtual weight" to them in game, takes getting used to but adds to the immersion. You must balance your resources and stamina (especially when climbing!). The more you take with you from "the hub", the less space you have to store scavenged stuff to bring back "home". This "Junk" can then be recycled giving you resources to upgrade your workbenches, making more items and abilities available.

To survive you need to adapt your tactics. Early on you can rely on sneaking up and "braining" zombies. Smash a bottle over their heads and then stab them, or use that Kitchen knife from the house you were just in. That'll soon change and you need to think on your feet, to get the best of the undead...the living too!

Those reviews complaining you can't crouch IRL, a patch has already been released. Check the release notes for the ini file to edit, to test the feature until they are happy with the mechanic and put it in game proper.
